unit_title: Rolling Without Slipping: Combined Translation and Rotation
subject: AP Physics C: Mechanics
expanded_description: This unit explores the sophisticated dynamics of rolling without slipping, where objects exhibit both translational and rotational motion simultaneously. Students will master the kinematic constraints, energy relationships, and force analyses unique to rolling motion, and apply these concepts to solve complex problems involving various geometric shapes rolling on different surfaces.
learning_objectives: Apply the rolling without slipping condition v_cm = Rω and a_cm = Rα
Analyze rolling motion using both force and energy methods
Solve problems involving objects rolling on inclines and curved paths
Calculate static friction requirements for rolling without slipping
Analyze rolling race problems between different geometric shapes
Apply rolling dynamics to real-world mechanical systems
prerequisites: Proficiency with moment of inertia calculations (Units 5.2-5.3)
Familiarity with friction concepts and Newton's laws
Ability to solve systems of equations with constraints

principles.principle: Kinematics and Constraints of Rolling Motion
principles.statement: Rolling without slipping involves coupled translational and rotational motion: Fundamental Constraints: Velocity: v_cm = Rω (center of mass velocity); Acceleration: a_cm = Rα (center of mass acceleration); Contact point has zero velocity relative to surface. Velocity Distribution: Center of mass: v_cm forward; Top point: v_top = v_cm + Rω = 2v_cm (forward); Bottom (contact) point: v_bottom = v_cm - Rω = 0; Side points: combination of components. Instantaneous Center of Rotation: For rolling without slipping, the contact point is instantaneously at rest; The entire object rotates instantaneously about the contact point; Useful for velocity calculations. Position and Angle Relationship: Distance traveled: s = Rθ; Linear displacement equals arc length; Valid for pure rolling. Acceleration Relationships: Linear acceleration of CM related to angular acceleration; Tangential acceleration at different points; Centripetal acceleration for curved paths. Different Geometric Shapes: Same constraints apply to all rigid bodies; Different mass distributions affect dynamics but not pure kinematics; Moment of inertia determines energy distribution. Problem-Solving Approach: 1. Identify rolling condition; 2. Apply constraint equations; 3. Use appropriate kinematic equations; 4. Solve for unknown quantities; 5. Verify physical reasonableness.
principles.application: Apply rolling constraints to various geometric shapes. Analyze velocity distributions on rolling objects. Use instantaneous center method for velocity calculations. Solve kinematic problems involving rolling motion. Determine position and orientation relationships. Analyze accelerated rolling scenarios.
principles.example: Vehicle wheel motion analysis. Ball rolling on flat surface. Cylinder rolling down incline. Gear meshing in machinery. Conveyor belt systems. Sports ball dynamics.
principles.analogy: Rolling without slipping is like a tank track moving - each track segment makes temporary contact with the ground (instantaneous center), then lifts off as the tank moves forward, with the overall motion combining the forward movement of the vehicle (translation) and the circular motion of the tracks (rotation), perfectly synchronized so no sliding occurs at the contact points

worked_examples.title: Velocity Analysis of Rolling Wheel
worked_examples.problem: A wheel of radius R rolls without slipping with center velocity v. Find the velocities of points at the top, bottom, and side of the wheel relative to the ground.

step_by_step.explanation: For any point: v_point = v_cm + ω × r (vector sum)
v_top = v_cm + ω × (R↑) = v→ + (v/R)(R) → = v→ + v→ = 2v→
v_bottom = v_cm + ω × (R↓) = v→ + (v/R)(-R) → = v→ - v→ = 0
v_side = v_cm + ω × (R→) = v→ + (v/R)(R) ↑ = v→ + v↑
Contact point instantaneously at rest; Top point moves fastest at 2v; Side points move at 45° angles

worked_examples.final_answer: Top: 2v forward; Bottom: 0; Side: v√2 at 45° upward

image.caption: Velocity analysis for points on a rolling wheel

worked_examples.title: Accelerated Rolling Kinematics
worked_examples.problem: A solid cylinder starts from rest and rolls without slipping down an incline. After 3 seconds, it has moved 9m down the incline. Find the cylinder's radius.

step_by_step.explanation: s = ½a_cm t² → 9 = ½a_cm (3)² → 9 = 4.5a_cm → a_cm = 2 m/s²
Use dynamics or energy; From energy: a_cm = g sinθ / (1 + I/(MR²))
I = ½MR² → I/(MR²) = ½ → a_cm = g sinθ / (1 + ½) = (2/3)g sinθ
Cannot find R from given information alone; Need additional constraint
The distance traveled relates to both linear and angular motion through s = Rθ
Equation is automatically satisfied; R cancels out; Cannot determine R from kinematics alone

worked_examples.final_answer: Radius cannot be determined from given kinematic information alone; Additional constraints needed

principles.principle: Dynamics and Energy of Rolling Motion
principles.statement: Rolling dynamics involves combined application of Newton's laws and energy principles: Force Analysis: Translation: ΣF = ma_cm; Rotation: Στ = Iα; For rolling without slipping: a_cm = Rα; Static friction provides necessary torque. Role of Friction: Static friction required for accelerated rolling; Does zero work in pure rolling (v_contact=0); Determines maximum acceleration without slipping; f_s ≤ μ_s N. Energy Considerations: Total KE = ½mv_cm² + ½Iω²; For rolling: ω = v_cm/R, so KE = ½(m + I/R²)v²; Effective mass concept. Energy Conservation: For conservative systems: mgh = ½(m + I/R²)v²; Acceleration: a_cm = g sinθ / (1 + I/(mR²)). Common Objects: Solid sphere: I = ⅖mR² → a = (5/7)g sinθ; Solid cylinder: I = ½mR² → a = (2/3)g sinθ; Hollow cylinder: I = mR² → a = (½)g sinθ. Problem-Solving Strategies: Force method: Write F=ma and τ=Iα, use a=Rα, solve system; Energy method: Use conservation, often simpler; Choice depends on needed information. Applications: Incline problems; Rolling race scenarios; Vehicle acceleration; Braking systems; Mechanical advantage systems.
principles.application: Analyze forces in rolling motion on inclines. Calculate static friction requirements. Apply energy conservation to rolling systems. Solve rolling race problems. Determine acceleration for different shapes. Analyze braking and deceleration in rolling.
principles.example: Objects rolling down ramps (which wins?). Vehicle acceleration and braking. Ball rolling on various surfaces. Industrial roller systems. Sports equipment dynamics. Conveyor system design.
principles.analogy: Rolling dynamics is like a coordinated dance partnership - the forward motion (translation) and spinning motion (rotation) must stay perfectly synchronized (v=Rω), with static friction acting as the connection that maintains this synchronization without energy loss, while different dance styles (object shapes) require different levels of coordination effort (friction requirements) to maintain the perfect timing

worked_examples.title: Sphere Rolling Down Incline with Friction Analysis
worked_examples.problem: A solid sphere rolls without slipping down an incline of angle 30°. Find the acceleration and the minimum coefficient of static friction needed.

step_by_step.explanation: Weight mg downward; Normal force N; Static friction f_s up incline
ma = mg sinθ - f_s (down incline positive)
From rotation: f_s R = (⅖mR²)(a/R) → f_s = ⅖ma
ma = mg sinθ - ⅖ma → ma + ⅖ma = mg sinθ → (7/5)ma = mg sinθ
Acceleration 3.5 m/s² is less than sliding value 4.9 m/s²; Requires μ ≥ 0.165

image.caption: Force analysis for sphere rolling down incline

worked_examples.title: Energy Method for Rolling Acceleration
worked_examples.problem: A hollow cylinder (I=mR²) rolls without slipping from rest down an incline of height h. Find the speed at the bottom using energy conservation.

step_by_step.explanation: E_f = ½mv² + ½(mR²)(v²/R²) = ½mv² + ½mv² = mv²
Solid sphere: v = √(10gh/7) ≈ √(1.429gh); Solid cylinder: v = √(4gh/3) ≈ √(1.333gh); Hollow cylinder: v = √(gh)
Hollow cylinder slowest because most energy goes to rotation; Solid sphere fastest
From v² = 2as with s = h/sinθ, a = (v² sinθ)/(2h) = (gh sinθ)/(2h) = ½g sinθ

image.caption: Energy method for rolling object on incline

worked_examples.title: Rolling on a Banked Curve
worked_examples.problem: A car travels at 20 m/s around a banked curve of radius 50m. The curve is banked at 15°. Determine if the car can negotiate the curve without relying on friction, and find the required friction if not.

step_by_step.explanation: Actual θ = 15° < 39.2°, so friction needed toward center
N sinθ + f cosθ = mv²/R (horizontal); N cosθ - f sinθ = mg (vertical)
From vertical: N = mg/(cosθ - μ sinθ) assuming f = μN; Better to solve generally
f = m[v²/R cosθ - g sinθ] / [sin²θ + cos²θ] = m[v²/R cosθ - g sinθ]
Substantial friction needed (μ=0.45) because banking is insufficient

worked_examples.final_answer: Friction required: μ = 0.45 toward center of curve

worked_examples.title: Transition from Slipping to Rolling
worked_examples.problem: A billiard ball is struck with a cue stick, giving it initial velocity v₀ but no initial rotation. If μ_k = 0.2, find how long it takes to start rolling without slipping and the final velocity.

step_by_step.explanation: Friction f_k = μ_k mg opposite to motion

step_by_step.step: Angular velocity as function of time

step_by_step.explanation: v₀ - μ_k g t = R × [(5/2)μ_k g t/R] = (5/2)μ_k g t
v₀ - μ_k g t = (5/2)μ_k g t → v₀ = (7/2)μ_k g t → t = (2v₀)/(7μ_k g)
v_f = v₀ - μ_k g t = v₀ - μ_k g (2v₀)/(7μ_k g) = v₀ - (2/7)v₀ = (5/7)v₀
Initial KE: ½mv₀²; Final KE: ½mv_f² + ½Iω_f² = ½m(25/49)v₀² + ½(⅖mR²)(25/49)(v₀²/R²) = (25/98 + 10/98)mv₀² = (35/98)mv₀² = (5/14)mv₀²; Fraction lost: 1 - 5/14 = 9/14 ≈ 64%

worked_examples.final_answer: Time to start rolling: t = 2v₀/(7μ_kg); Final velocity: v_f = (5/7)v₀

Confusing static and kinetic friction in rolling
Believing the contact point has absolute zero velocity
Thinking all rolling objects accelerate equally down inclines

Thinking rolling friction is the same as sliding friction

summary: Rolling without slipping represents a sophisticated form of rigid body motion that combines translation and rotation through the fundamental constraints v_cm = Rω and a_cm = Rα. This unique motion involves static friction that enables acceleration without energy dissipation, distinct velocity distributions across the object, and an instantaneous center of rotation at the contact point. Through careful analysis of forces, energy distributions, and kinematic constraints, we can solve complex problems involving various geometric shapes rolling on different surfaces, including inclined planes, curved paths, and banked curves. The advanced concepts of rolling-slipping transitions, unusual mass distributions, and real-world applications demonstrate the power and versatility of rolling dynamics across engineering, physics, and technology, providing essential tools for analyzing and designing systems where efficient motion with minimal energy loss is crucial.
